results.title: Teenage blues
results.creator_credit: Garry Dunstan, Pat Hunder, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and It's About Time
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
An episode on boredom, boredom and more boredom. Teenagers, in a set of comic sketches, explore the “nowhere to go, nothing to do syndrome”. Once they take up the challenge of organising the school social, they realise that a creative and positive approach to overcoming boredom can solve the problem.

results.title: Beating about the bush
results.creator_credit: Caroline Sherwood, Nicholas Adler and Titus Films
results.brief_description: The film follows the tour of Djaambi, a half Aboriginal, half white, urban band from Melbourne, under the leadership of Richard Frankland as they travel to remote Aboriginal communities in outback Australia. It explores the cultural mix within the band and the culture shock all members of the band, particularly the Aboriginal members, experience as they meet another, very different side of their culture. Towards the end of the tour the various problems and cultural confusions become focused in a radical split between the white film makers and the more vocal Aboriginal band members. A disturbing look at good intentions gone wrong.

results.title: Deep in my heart
results.creator_credit: Stanley Donen, Roger Edens and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: This film ‘biopic’ portrays the life of composer Sigmund Romberg, whose scores included “The Desert Song” and “Maytime”. While Broadway swings to the jazzy beat of ragtime, Romberg chooses to play the beautiful waltzes of his native country. When Romberg is convinced by the owner of the Cafe Vienna to try his hand at ragtime he writes a hit song in no time at all. Romberg writes one smash hit after another and eventually creates a hit show that takes Broadway by storm. Based on the book by Elliot Arnold. Stars Jose Ferrer, Merle Oberon, Helen Traubel, Walter Pidgeon with special guest appearances by Ann Miller, Rosemary Clooney, Cyd Charisse, Gene Kelly and Howard Keel.

results.title: Sentimental imperialists
results.creator_credit: Marc Levin, Al Levin, Jigsaw Productions, KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.), Nihon Hoso Kyokai, PBI Productions and Teleac Holland
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Pacific century”.
This program looks at American attitudes towards Asia, from 1776 to the present. This is the story of merchants, missionaries and U.S. marines who, however well-intentioned, often saw in Asia what they wanted to see, rather than what was really there. The episode focuses on China and the Philippines, where policies of cold calculation mingled with deep sentiment for the region continue to influence US relations with Asia.

results.title: The Fight for democracy
results.creator_credit: Carl Byker, Jigsaw Productions, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, PBI Productions and Teleac Holland
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Pacific century”.
This program uses the recent history of South Korea to look at the way economic success in South East Asia is leading to greater democracy. A union member, a journalist, a women’s rights activist and a successful businessman are four characters in a powerful, emotional story of people demanding a greater stake and a say in the way their nation is run. A study guide and faculty manual are available to accompany this series.

results.title: The Edge of forever
results.creator_credit: David F. Oyster, Gregory Andorfer, Adrian Malone, BBC Film Unit, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
What is the origin of the universe? What is its fate? Will it continue to expand forever, or someday collapse upon itself? Carl Sagan explores the time when stars and galaxies began to form, and shows how, in this century, humans discovered the expansion of the universe. He also explores the philosophical and religious questions that these musings create. Topics discussed along the way include galaxies and their many different forms, the Doppler effect, tessaracts, the Big Bang and quasars.

results.title: Journeys in space and time
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and Polytel International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
In this episode Carl Sagan explores the relationship of space and time. He begins by showing how the shape of the constellations would change over millions of years, as the stars move and evolve, and then launches into a discussion on the speed of light and Einstein’s theory of relativity, concluding with the tantalising possibilities of time travel and parallel universes.

results.title: Introducing the Eucalypts
results.creator_credit: Paul Broady and Video Education Australia
results.brief_description: This program covers the main features of our Eucalypts: their identifying characteristics (especially the bark, flower buds and leaves), adaptability, distribution patterns, growth and type of timber produced, and their human and non-human uses.

results.title: Crackpot, jackpot: Human contrasts and survival
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Botanic man”.
This program takes a look at the problems caused by the high energy consumption of modern countries and some possible solutions. It contrasts life in California, the inhabitants of a tower block who live in a completely controlled environment and the inhabitants of Mexico where Indians are farming land which is rich in oil and great changes are about to embrace them.

results.title: A Safety net
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Battle for the planet”.
The presenter of this program, Professor Eddie Ayensu of Ghana, is a leading African commentator on development issues. His concern in this program is what he sees as the damage which food aid does to African economics. To him, this aid creates a psychological dependence in the minds of farmers and acts as a disincentive to their own production. Ayensu says food aid was originally intended to provide African countries with room to manoeuvre, but now unwanted foods (such as sugar) is virtually being dumped. He looks at the staple foods in Africa such as Cassava, fish and fruit and makes the point that if Western aid went into improving productivity in these industries, African food production would be much more efficient and better able to feed the population.
